repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Province of Santa Fe Road
            Infrastructure Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Province of Santa Fe
            Road Infrastructure Project for Argentina were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was satisfactory and borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: the Bank is well equipped to provide added value
            to projects of this nature, ensuring that road safety and
            environmental management protocols are adequately integrated
            into project design and implementation. The establishment of
            unified environmental standards for all contractors involved
            in project execution is a practice worth replicating in
            similar projects. The establishment of formal channels for
            continued feedback from users and civil society provided a
            vital instrument for guaranteeing successful project
            implementation, enabling inclusion of citizens'
            perspectives and knowledge in the actual design of projects,
            strengthening ownership by local communities, and
            democratizing the overall process. Operations should provide
            for appropriate due diligence in urban projects, minimizing
            the risk of encountering unforeseen contingencies,
            particularly in the provision of utilities (electricity,
            water), which can increase costs and delay implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Province of Santa Fe Road
            Infrastructure Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall purpose of the Province of
            Santa Fe Road Infrastructure Project for Argentina is to
            improve transport conditions along a strategic road corridor
            that links the Province of Santa Fe with regional and
            international markets. The reallocation is necessary to be
            able to use the funds currently in the
            'unallocated' category set forth in the loan
            agreement. This reallocation will not change the percentage
            of financing. The main component of this project, the
            upgrading of National Road 19, will receive the full amount
            of the unallocated funds. The construction works along
            National Road 19 are progressing according to the work plan
            set forth at the time of the bidding and no cost overruns
            have been observed. The total costs of the upgrading works
            will reach US$175 million and consequently the reallocation
            will allow to approximate the percentage of financing (the
            Province of Santa Fe will provide additional resources if
            necessary as counterpart funds). The upgraded Road 19, with
            the exception of 2km in the City of Santo Tome will be
            completed in June 2011, with the remaining works expected to
            be completed by February, 2012. Closing date of this Project
            is June 30, 2012.

Argentina - Province of Santa Fe
            Road Infrastructure Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Santa Fe Road Infrastructure
            Project : inspection panel investigation report

abstracts.cdata!:
The inspection panel submitted its
            investigation report on the Santa Fe Road Infrastructure
            Project to the Board of Executive Directors on July 2, 2009.
            On August 13, 2009, Management submitted its Report and
            Recommendations (MRR), including a detailed Management
            Action Plan (MAP) developed in response to the inspection
            panel's investigation report. Management has taken
            action on all items of the MAP, and implementation has been
            substantially completed. The counterpart entity (the
            Government of the Province of Santa Fe) has followed through
            on the implementation of the MAP by: (i) exchanging views
            with the project team on the results of the study (an
            ongoing process as of June 2010 that will involve meetings
            with the consulting firm, the Project Implementation Unit
            (PIU) and the provincial Secretary of Water Affairs); (ii)
            implementing the communications and consultations strategy
            as agreed in the Environmental and Social Management Plan
            (ESMP); and (iii) fully complying with its responsibility in
            supervising the construction works. In addition, it has
            supported the elaboration of a Strategic Environmental
            Assessment (SEA).
